segment.source: You can use both Windows.Networking.Sockets and Winsock to communicate with other devices as a Universal Windows Platform (UWP) app developer.
segment.target: You can use both Windows.Networking.Sockets and Winsock to communicate with other devices as a Universal Windows Platform (UWP) app developer.

segment.source: Sockets
segment.target: Sockets

segment.source: Sockets
segment.target: Sockets

segment.source: Updated for UWP apps on Windows 10.
segment.target: Updated for UWP apps on Windows 10.

segment.source: For Windows 8.x articles, see the archive
segment.target: For Windows 8.x articles, see the archive

segment.source: Important APIs
segment.target: Important APIs

segment.source: Windows.Networking.Sockets
segment.target: Windows.Networking.Sockets

segment.source: Winsock
segment.target: Winsock

segment.source: You can use both Windows.Networking.Sockets and Winsock to communicate with other devices as a Universal Windows Platform (UWP) app developer.
segment.target: You can use both Windows.Networking.Sockets and Winsock to communicate with other devices as a Universal Windows Platform (UWP) app developer.

segment.source: This topic provides in-depth guidance on using the Windows.Networking.Sockets namespace to perform networking operations.
segment.target: This topic provides in-depth guidance on using the Windows.Networking.Sockets namespace to perform networking operations.

segment.source: Note As part of network isolation, the system forbids establishing socket connections (Sockets or WinSock) between two UWP apps running on the same machine via either the local loopback address (127.0.0.0) or explicitly specifying the local IP address.
segment.target: Note As part of network isolation, the system forbids establishing socket connections (Sockets or WinSock) between two UWP apps running on the same machine via either the local loopback address (127.0.0.0) or explicitly specifying the local IP address.

segment.source: This means that you cannot use sockets to communicate between two UWP apps.
segment.target: This means that you cannot use sockets to communicate between two UWP apps.

segment.source: UWP supplies other mechanisms for communicating between apps.
segment.target: UWP supplies other mechanisms for communicating between apps.

segment.source: See App-to-app communications for details.
segment.target: See App-to-app communications for details.

segment.source: Basic TCP socket operations
segment.target: Basic TCP socket operations

segment.source: A TCP socket provides low-level network data transfers in either direction for long-lived connections.
segment.target: A TCP socket provides low-level network data transfers in either direction for long-lived connections.

segment.source: TCP sockets are the underlying feature used by most of the network protocols used on the Internet.
segment.target: TCP sockets are the underlying feature used by most of the network protocols used on the Internet.

segment.source: This section shows how to enable a UWP app to send and receive data with a TCP stream socket using the StreamSocket and StreamSocketListener classes as part of the Windows.Networking.Sockets namespace.
segment.target: This section shows how to enable a UWP app to send and receive data with a TCP stream socket using the StreamSocket and StreamSocketListener classes as part of the Windows.Networking.Sockets namespace.

segment.source: For this section, we will be creating a very simple app that will function as an echo server and client to demonstrate basic TCP operations.
segment.target: For this section, we will be creating a very simple app that will function as an echo server and client to demonstrate basic TCP operations.

segment.source: Creating a TCP echo server
segment.target: Creating a TCP echo server

segment.source: The following code example demonstrates how to create a StreamSocketListener object and start listening for incoming TCP connections.
segment.target: The following code example demonstrates how to create a StreamSocketListener object and start listening for incoming TCP connections.

segment.source: The following code example implements the SocketListenerConnectionReceived event handler that was attached to the StreamSocketListener.ConnectionReceived event in the above example.
segment.target: The following code example implements the SocketListenerConnectionReceived event handler that was attached to the StreamSocketListener.ConnectionReceived event in the above example.

segment.source: This event handler is called by the StreamSocketListener class every time a remote client has established a connection with the echo server.
segment.target: This event handler is called by the StreamSocketListener class every time a remote client has established a connection with the echo server.

segment.source: Creating a TCP echo client
segment.target: Creating a TCP echo client

segment.source: The following code example demonstrates how to create a StreamSocket object, establish a connection to the remote server, send a request, and receive a response.
segment.target: The following code example demonstrates how to create a StreamSocket object, establish a connection to the remote server, send a request, and receive a response.

segment.source: Basic UDP socket operations
segment.target: Basic UDP socket operations

segment.source: A UDP socket provides low-level network data transfers in either direction for network communication that does not require an established connection.
segment.target: A UDP socket provides low-level network data transfers in either direction for network communication that does not require an established connection.

segment.source: Because UDP sockets do not maintain connection on both endpoints they provide fast and simple solution for networking between remote machines.
segment.target: Because UDP sockets do not maintain connection on both endpoints they provide fast and simple solution for networking between remote machines.

segment.source: However, UDP sockets do not ensure integrity of the network packets or whether they make it to the remote destination at all.
segment.target: However, UDP sockets do not ensure integrity of the network packets or whether they make it to the remote destination at all.

segment.source: Some examples of applications that use UDP sockets are local network discovery and local chat clients.
segment.target: Some examples of applications that use UDP sockets are local network discovery and local chat clients.

segment.source: This section demonstrates the use of the DatagramSocket class to sending and receiving UDP messages by creating a simple echo server and client.
segment.target: This section demonstrates the use of the DatagramSocket class to sending and receiving UDP messages by creating a simple echo server and client.

segment.source: Creating a UDP echo server
segment.target: Creating a UDP echo server

segment.source: The following code example demonstrates how to create a DatagramSocket object and bind it to a specific port so that you can listen for incoming UDP messages.
segment.target: The following code example demonstrates how to create a DatagramSocket object and bind it to a specific port so that you can listen for incoming UDP messages.

segment.source: The following code example implements the SocketMessageReceived event handler to read a message that was received from a client and send the same message back.
segment.target: The following code example implements the SocketMessageReceived event handler to read a message that was received from a client and send the same message back.

segment.source: Creating a UDP echo client
segment.target: Creating a UDP echo client

segment.source: The following code example demonstrates how to create a DatagramSocket object and bind it to a specific port so that you can listen for incoming UDP messages and send a UDP message to the UDP echo server.
segment.target: The following code example demonstrates how to create a DatagramSocket object and bind it to a specific port so that you can listen for incoming UDP messages and send a UDP message to the UDP echo server.

segment.source: The following code example implements the SocketMessageReceived event handler to read a message that was received from the UDP echo server.
segment.target: The following code example implements the SocketMessageReceived event handler to read a message that was received from the UDP echo server.

segment.source: Background operations and the socket broker
segment.target: Background operations and the socket broker

segment.source: If your app receives connections or data on sockets, then you must be prepared to perform those operations properly while your app is not in the foreground.
segment.target: If your app receives connections or data on sockets, then you must be prepared to perform those operations properly while your app is not in the foreground.

segment.source: To do so, you use the socket broker.
segment.target: To do so, you use the socket broker.

segment.source: For more information on how to use the socket broker, see Network communications in the background.
segment.target: For more information on how to use the socket broker, see Network communications in the background.

segment.source: Batched sends
segment.target: Batched sends

segment.source: Starting with Windows 10, Windows.Networking.Sockets supports batched sends, a way for you to send multiple buffers of data together with much lower context-switching overhead than if you send each of the buffers separately.
segment.target: Starting with Windows 10, Windows.Networking.Sockets supports batched sends, a way for you to send multiple buffers of data together with much lower context-switching overhead than if you send each of the buffers separately.

segment.source: This is especially useful if your app is doing VoIP, VPN, or other tasks which involve moving a lot of data as efficiently as possible.
segment.target: This is especially useful if your app is doing VoIP, VPN, or other tasks which involve moving a lot of data as efficiently as possible.

segment.source: Each call to WriteAsync on a socket triggers a kernel transition to reach the network stack.
segment.target: Each call to WriteAsync on a socket triggers a kernel transition to reach the network stack.

segment.source: When an app writes many buffers at a time, each write incurs a separate kernel transition, and this creates substantial overhead.
segment.target: When an app writes many buffers at a time, each write incurs a separate kernel transition, and this creates substantial overhead.

segment.source: The new batched sends pattern optimizes the frequency of kernel transitions.
segment.target: The new batched sends pattern optimizes the frequency of kernel transitions.

segment.source: This functionality is currently limited to StreamSocket and connected DatagramSocket instances.
segment.target: This functionality is currently limited to StreamSocket and connected DatagramSocket instances.

segment.source: Here is an example of how an app would send a large number of buffers in a non-optimal way.
segment.target: Here is an example of how an app would send a large number of buffers in a non-optimal way.

segment.source: This example shows a more efficient way to send a large number of buffers.
segment.target: This example shows a more efficient way to send a large number of buffers.

segment.source: Because this technique uses features unique to the C# language, it is only available to C# programmers.
segment.target: Because this technique uses features unique to the C# language, it is only available to C# programmers.

segment.source: By sending multiple packets at a time, this example enables the system to batch sends, and thus optimize kernel transitions for improved performance.
segment.target: By sending multiple packets at a time, this example enables the system to batch sends, and thus optimize kernel transitions for improved performance.

segment.source: This example shows another way to send a large number of buffers in a way that's compatible with batched sends.
segment.target: This example shows another way to send a large number of buffers in a way that's compatible with batched sends.

segment.source: And since it doesn't use any C#-specific features, it is applicable for all languages (though it is demonstrated here in C#).
segment.target: And since it doesn't use any C#-specific features, it is applicable for all languages (though it is demonstrated here in C#).

segment.source: Instead, it uses changed behavior in the OutputStream member of the StreamSocket and DatagramSocket classes that is new in Windows 10.
segment.target: Instead, it uses changed behavior in the OutputStream member of the StreamSocket and DatagramSocket classes that is new in Windows 10.

segment.source: In earlier versions of Windows, FlushAsync returned immediately, and did not guarantee that all operations on the stream had completed yet.
segment.target: In earlier versions of Windows, FlushAsync returned immediately, and did not guarantee that all operations on the stream had completed yet.

segment.source: In Windows 10, the behavior has changed.
segment.target: In Windows 10, the behavior has changed.

segment.source: FlushAsync is now guaranteed to return after all operations on the output stream have completed.
segment.target: FlushAsync is now guaranteed to return after all operations on the output stream have completed.

segment.source: There are some important limitations imposed by using batched writes in your code.
segment.target: There are some important limitations imposed by using batched writes in your code.

segment.source: You cannot modify the contents of the IBuffer instances being written until the asynchronous write is complete.
segment.target: You cannot modify the contents of the IBuffer instances being written until the asynchronous write is complete.

segment.source: The FlushAsync pattern only works on StreamSocket.OutputStream and DatagramSocket.OutputStream.
segment.target: The FlushAsync pattern only works on StreamSocket.OutputStream and DatagramSocket.OutputStream.

segment.source: The FlushAsync pattern only works in Windows 10 and onward.
segment.target: The FlushAsync pattern only works in Windows 10 and onward.

segment.source: In other cases, use Task.WaitAll instead of the FlushAsync pattern.
segment.target: In other cases, use Task.WaitAll instead of the FlushAsync pattern.

segment.source: Port sharing for DatagramSocket
segment.target: Port sharing for DatagramSocket

segment.source: Windows 10 introduces a new DatagramSocketControl property, MulticastOnly, which enables you to specify that the DatagramSocket in question is able to coexist with other Win32 or WinRT multicast sockets bound to the same address/port.
segment.target: Windows 10 introduces a new DatagramSocketControl property, MulticastOnly, which enables you to specify that the DatagramSocket in question is able to coexist with other Win32 or WinRT multicast sockets bound to the same address/port.

segment.source: Providing a client certificate with the StreamSocket class
segment.target: Providing a client certificate with the StreamSocket class

segment.source: The Windows.Networking.StreamSocket class supports using SSL/TLS to authenticate the server the app is talking to.
segment.target: The Windows.Networking.StreamSocket class supports using SSL/TLS to authenticate the server the app is talking to.

segment.source: In certain cases, the app also needs to authenticate itself to the server using a TLS client certificate.
segment.target: In certain cases, the app also needs to authenticate itself to the server using a TLS client certificate.

segment.source: In Windows 10, you can provide a client certificate on the StreamSocket.Control object (this must be set before the TLS handshake is started).
segment.target: In Windows 10, you can provide a client certificate on the StreamSocket.Control object (this must be set before the TLS handshake is started).

segment.source: If the server requests the client certificate, Windows will respond with the certificate provided.
segment.target: If the server requests the client certificate, Windows will respond with the certificate provided.

segment.source: Here is a code snippet showing how to implement this:
segment.target: Here is a code snippet showing how to implement this:

segment.source: Exceptions in Windows.Networking.Sockets
segment.target: Exceptions in Windows.Networking.Sockets

segment.source: The constructor for the HostName class used with sockets can throw an exception if the string passed is not a valid hostname (contains characters that are not allowed in a host name).
segment.target: The constructor for the HostName class used with sockets can throw an exception if the string passed is not a valid hostname (contains characters that are not allowed in a host name).

segment.source: If an app gets input from the user for the HostName, the constructor should be in a try/catch block.
segment.target: If an app gets input from the user for the HostName, the constructor should be in a try/catch block.

segment.source: If an exception is thrown, the app can notify the user and request a new hostname.
segment.target: If an exception is thrown, the app can notify the user and request a new hostname.

segment.source: The Windows.Networking.Sockets namespace has convenient helper methods and enumerations for handling errors when using sockets and WebSockets.
segment.target: The Windows.Networking.Sockets namespace has convenient helper methods and enumerations for handling errors when using sockets and WebSockets.

segment.source: This can be useful for handling specific network exceptions differently in your app.
segment.target: This can be useful for handling specific network exceptions differently in your app.

segment.source: An error encountered on DatagramSocket, StreamSocket, or StreamSocketListener operation is returned as an HRESULT value.
segment.target: An error encountered on DatagramSocket, StreamSocket, or StreamSocketListener operation is returned as an HRESULT value.

segment.source: The SocketError.GetStatus method is used to convert a network error from a socket operation to a SocketErrorStatus enumeration value.
segment.target: The SocketError.GetStatus method is used to convert a network error from a socket operation to a SocketErrorStatus enumeration value.

segment.source: Most of the SocketErrorStatus enumeration values correspond to an error returned by the native Windows sockets operation.
segment.target: Most of the SocketErrorStatus enumeration values correspond to an error returned by the native Windows sockets operation.

segment.source: An app can filter on specific SocketErrorStatus enumeration values to modify app behavior depending on the cause of the exception.
segment.target: An app can filter on specific SocketErrorStatus enumeration values to modify app behavior depending on the cause of the exception.

segment.source: An error encountered on a MessageWebSocket or StreamWebSocket operation is returned as an HRESULT value.
segment.target: An error encountered on a MessageWebSocket or StreamWebSocket operation is returned as an HRESULT value.

segment.source: The WebSocketError.GetStatus method is used to convert a network error from a WebSocket operation to a WebErrorStatus enumeration value.
segment.target: The WebSocketError.GetStatus method is used to convert a network error from a WebSocket operation to a WebErrorStatus enumeration value.

segment.source: Most of the WebErrorStatus enumeration values correspond to an error returned by the native HTTP client operation.
segment.target: Most of the WebErrorStatus enumeration values correspond to an error returned by the native HTTP client operation.

segment.source: An app can filter on specific WebErrorStatus enumeration values to modify app behavior depending on the cause of the exception.
segment.target: An app can filter on specific WebErrorStatus enumeration values to modify app behavior depending on the cause of the exception.

segment.source: For parameter validation errors, an app can also use the HRESULT from the exception to learn more detailed information on the error that caused the exception.
segment.target: For parameter validation errors, an app can also use the HRESULT from the exception to learn more detailed information on the error that caused the exception.

segment.source: Possible HRESULT values are listed in the Winerror.h header file.
segment.target: Possible HRESULT values are listed in the Winerror.h header file.

segment.source: For most parameter validation errors, the HRESULT returned is EINVALIDARG.
segment.target: For most parameter validation errors, the HRESULT returned is EINVALIDARG.

segment.source: The Winsock API
segment.target: The Winsock API

segment.source: You can use Winsock in your UWP app, as well.
segment.target: You can use Winsock in your UWP app, as well.

segment.source: The supported Winsock API is based on that of Windows Phone 8.1Microsoft Silverlight and continues to support most of the types, properties and methods (some APIs that are considered obsolete have been removed).
segment.target: The supported Winsock API is based on that of Windows Phone 8.1Microsoft Silverlight and continues to support most of the types, properties and methods (some APIs that are considered obsolete have been removed).

segment.source: You can find more information on Winsock programming here.
segment.target: You can find more information on Winsock programming here.
